keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas due to the new Trump administration fee of $100,000.
The H-1B visa is a work visa valid for three years, renewable for another three, and widely used by tech and large corporations to hire skilled foreign workers.
Major tech firms and Walmart, which employs over 2,000 H-1B workers, are significantly affected by the new visa cost, which could disrupt talent acquisition.

The fee is justified by the Trump administration as a measure to curb abuse of the H-1B program, but critics argue it disproportionately impacts skilled professionals from India and increases costs for companies.
This policy shift illustrates how U.S. immigration policy changes under Trump are directly influencing corporate hiring practices and international talent flow.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., has paused job offers to foreign candidates requiring H-1B work visas following President Donald Trump’s announcement of a $100,000 fee on the visa program. This move, which comes amid broader criticism of the H-1B system's cost and accessibility, reflects a significant shift in corporate hiring policy due to political immigration reforms. The policy change is particularly impactful because it disproportionately affects skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B applicants. The article underscores how federal immigration policy decisions—such as Trump’s proposed fee—can directly influence corporate strategy, talent acquisition, and global competitiveness in the U.S. business environment.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
